facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 614 of 1961 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 614 of 1961. APpeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 428 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: APpeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, Hyderabad in Second Appeal No. 428 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri and T.V.R. Tatachari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants were plaintiffs in the trial court bringing suit in representative capacity on behalf of ryots of several villages irrigated by Gudur anicut system.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were the plaintiffs in the first court. They brought the suit in a representative capacity on behalf of the ryots of several villages whose lands are irrigated by what is locally known as the Gudur anicut system.

facts.text: Venkatagiri river flows west to east then turns south, passes Chennur, Gudur etc.

anchor.surface_text: There is a stream or small river known as Venkatagiri river which flows west to east and then takes a turn to the south. It passes by or near villages Chennur, Gudur, etc.

facts.text: Appellants' lands irrigated from four tanks; three from Venkatagiri river through channel from Gudur anicut at Ananthamadugu; fourth from same river via Pumbaleru anicut; plus direct channel Ac. 600; total Ac. 4000.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants was that from time immemorial their lands were irrigated from four tanks three of the tanks received their supply of water from the Venkatagiri river through a channel emanating from the Gudur anicut at a place called Ananthamadugu. The fourth tank also received its supply of water from the same river through a channel emanating from near the Pumbaleru anicut further down the river. In addition, a separate channel from the Pumbaleru anicut directly irrigated about Ac. 600--00 of land. It was stated that on the whole, about Ac. 4000--00 of the land of the appellants were irrigated in the manner indicated above under the Gudur anicut system.

facts.text: Chennur village ryots higher up the river had a tank and attempted to secure water by constructing anicut at Gollapalli about one mile up, attempts failed in 1929-1930.

anchor.surface_text: The ryots of Chennur a village situate higher up the river, had also a tank for irrigating their lands. These ryots made several attempts to secure a portion of the water of Venkatagiri river by having an anicut constructed over the river at a place called Gollapalli, about one mile up the river, in order to get supply of water to Chennur tank by means of a supply channel emanating from near the place of the proposed Gollapalli anicut. These attempts failed in 1929-1930.

facts.text: In 1935, Madras Government passed G.O. No. 2241/1 dated October 16, 1935 directing construction of anicut at Gollapalli for Chennur tank with safeguards.

anchor.surface_text: But they renewed their attempts and in 1935, the Madras Government passed an order  G. O. No. 2241/1 dated October 16, 1935  directing the construction of an anicut at Gollapalli for supply of water to the Chennur tank with certain safeguards to ensure that the supply to the Gudur anicut system was not adversely affected and to utilise only the excess water going to waste during the flood season for the Chennur tank.

facts.text: Appellants objected to G.O. 2241/1 dated October 16, 1935; matter investigated, G.O. No. 1161 dated May 6, 1939 issued modifying earlier order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants objected to the scheme of G.O. No. 2241/1 dated October 16 1935 and the matter was further investigated by Government. Finally, G.O. No. 1161 dated May 6, 1939, was issued modifying the earlier order in some respects.

facts.text: Masonry anicut known as Chennur anicut constructed in 1944 per G.O. 1161, details in Ex. A-6 and para 11 of plaint; consisted of free portion 61 ft west, fixed 11.4 ft, planked only in flood.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that order, a masonry anicut known as the Chennur anicut was constructed in 1944, the details whereof were stated in Ex. A-6 and summarised in paragraph 11 of the plaint. With those details we are not at present concerned, except merely to state that the anicut consisted of two portions a free portion 61 feet long on the west and a fixed portion about 11. 4 feet long, the free portion to be kept fully planked only when the river was in flood with a view to divert surplus water to Chennur tank and- was not to be planked until the Gudur anicut was surplusing.

facts.text: Chennur ryots did not stick to arrangements of G.O. 1161 dated May 6, 1939; renewed attempts for larger supply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants alleged that the Chennur ryots did not stick to the arrangements made as a result of G. O No. 1161 dated May 6, 1939, but renewed their attempts for getting a larger supply of water from Venkatagiri river

facts.text: State Government passed order in 1952 directing: i) extension of Chennur anicut by 46 ft, ii) removal of dam stones/planks and construct permanent masonry wall 175 ft, iii) raise height by 3 ft, iv) install three vents with shutters.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants came to know that behind their back and without notice to them, the State Government passed another order in 1952 in which they directed  i  the extension of the Chennur anicut by another 46 feet.,  ii  removal of the dam stones and planks altogether and the construction of a permanent masonry wall over the crest of the anicut to the entire length of 175 feet,  iii  raising the height of the wall by 3 feet more, and  iv  installation of three vents with screw-gearing-shutters for the flow of water down the Chennur anicut.

facts.text: G.O. Ms. 53 F. and A (F.P.) dated February 15, 1952 (Ex. B-1).

anchor.surface_text: The State Government did not purport to act under s. 3  1  when they passed G. O. Ms. 53 F. and A  F.P.  dated February 15, 1952,

facts.text: Appellants alleged 1952 alterations would seriously affect their water supply from Gudur anicut system, deprive during low supply periods.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants alleged that this would seriously affect their accustomed right to the supply of water from Venkatagiri river under the Gudur anicut system and practically deprive them of water during the low supply and spring periods.

facts.text: Plaintiffs prayed for declaration that defendant has no right to alter/extend/add to Chennur anicut; costs; further reliefs. No injunction as state bound by declaration.

anchor.surface_text: They, therefore, prayed for a decree-  a  declaring that the defendant has no right in the circumstances stated above to alter or extend or add to the Chennur anicut over Venkatagiri river at Gollapalli in any manner whatsoever  b  for costs of the suit and  c  and for such other and further reliefs as in the circumstances the court may deem fit and proper in the circumstances. They specifically said in the plaint that it was not necessary to ask for a permanent injunction as the defendant  meaning the State of Andhra Pradesh  was bound and certain to give effect to the declaration granted by the court.

facts.text: State of Andhra Pradesh initially sole defendant, later certain other defendants (Chennur ryots) added.

anchor.surface_text: At first, the State of Andhra Pradesh was the only defendant. Certain other defendants, presumably ryots of Chennur, were made parties-defendants on a later date.

facts.text: Written statement by State and 4th defendant averred proposed alterations would not injuriously affect appellants' rights.

anchor.surface_text: A written statement was filed by the State of Andhra Pradesh, as also by the 4th defendant, in which it was averred that the proposed alterations to the Chennur anicut would not injuriously affect the rights of the appellants and certain details were given as to the flow of water in the river at different times.

facts.text: Supplemental written statement by State pleaded s.4 of Act bars suit; taken as preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: By a supplemental written statement the defendant-State, respondent before us, took the plea that s. 4 of the Act was a bar to the entertainment of the suit. This plea was taken up for trial as a preliminary issue.

facts.text: Trial court held s.4 applies, dismissed suit on preliminary issue; appeal to District Judge failed; Second Appeal to High Court failed.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have dismissed the suit brought by the appellants, holding on a preliminary issue that S. 4 aforesaid applies and the suit cannot be entertained. ... An appeal to the District judge failed and so also a Second Appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Chennur tank and four tanks of appellants are irrigation tanks within meaning of the Act; no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Now,, there is no dispute before us that the Chennur tank as well as the four tanks from which the appellants get a supply of water for irrigating their lands are irrigation tanks within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Order dated February 15, 1952 (Ex. B-1) based on Board of Revenue communication dated April 8, 1950 (Ex. B-10) advising action under s.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rightly pointed out that the order dated February 15, 1952,  Ex. B-1  was based on the communication of the Board of Revenue dated April 8, 1950  Ex. B-10  and that communication states clearly enough that Government was advised that it could take action under s. 3  1  of the Act.

facts.text: No notice under r.5 of Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Rules, 1950 published at time of suit filing.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court rightly pointed out that the proposed action had not been taken when the appellants filed their suit and there was still time for the State Government to publish the notice under r. 5.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal with costs, upholds s.4 bars entertainment of suit.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we would dismiss this appeal with costs.

facts.text: Supply channel to Chennur tank emanates from near Chennur anicut on Venkatagiri river.

anchor.surface_text: The supply channel to the Chennur tank takes off water from the Venkatagiri river and it starts from near the Chennur anicut.

facts.text: Narasimham J. made observations on merits not justified as case not decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, point out that Narasimham, J., in the course of his judgment made some observations regarding the merits of the claim of the appellants which were not justified and may prejudice the appellants in subsequent proceedings.

s. 4 of the Madras Irrigation Tanks  Improvement  Act, 1949  Mad. XIX of 1949 , hereinafter referred to as the Act. The section is in these terms - No Court shall entertain any suit or appli- cation for the issue of an injunction to restrain the exercise of any powers companyferred on the Government by section- 3.

concepts.interpretation: Bars not only direct suits for injunction but also suits for declaration that effectively restrain the government from exercising powers under s.3(1), as it would circumvent s.4.

issues.text: Whether the finding of the courts below that s.4 of the Act applies and bars the entertainment of the suit is correct

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have dismissed the suit brought by the appellants, holding on a preliminary issue that S. 4 aforesaid applies and the suit cannot be entertained. The question before us is, whether this finding is correct. We must first state the relevant facts.

issues.text: Whether the proposed alterations to the Chennur anicut are within the powers conferred on the Government by s.3(1) of the Act or exceed them such that s.4 does not apply

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 3 1 of the Act are restricted to effecting improvements to a tank as defined in s.2 d , and such improvement covers, for example, raising the height or increasing the width of the band, or lengthening the wear, or extending the bed of the tat it may even extend to improving the supply channel but does number go any further the State Government in proposing the alterations in the Chennur anicut arc proposing to do something which is in excess of the powers given by s. 3 1 and, therefore, s. 4 does number bar the entertainment of the suit of the appellants.

issues.text: Whether s.4 bars only suits expressly for injunction or also the present suit for declaration which effectively restrains exercise of powers under s.3(1)

anchor.surface_text: On any view, s. 4 bars the entertainment of a suit for the issue of an injunction to restrain the exercise of powers conferred on the Government by s. 3 1 the present suit is number a suit for injunction and the appellants have specifically said that they do number ask for an injunction therefore, s. 4 is numberbar.

issues.text: Whether the State Government purported to act under s.3(1) and whether failure to publish notice under r.5 means s.4 does not apply

anchor.surface_text: The State Government did number purport to act under s. 3 1 when they passed G. O. Ms. 53 F. and A F.P. dated February 15, 1952, and as they did number issue a numberice as required by r. 5 of the Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Rules, 1050, the action proposed to be taken by them cannot companye under s. 3 1 therefore, s. 4 does number apply.

issues.text: Whether s.3(1) is ultra vires the Constitution such that s.4 falls with it

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1 is ultra vires the Constitution and s. 4 must fall within s.3.

issues.text: How far up the river can the State Government take measures under s.3(1) to improve a tank's efficiency

anchor.surface_text: A question was mooted before us as to how far the State Government can go up the river in order to improve the Chennur tank. Perhaps, the answer to that question is that the improvement measures proposed to be taken must have a direct and proximate relation to the tank, the efficiency of which is to be increased.

arguments.claim: Proposed alterations increase efficiency of Chennur tank by larger water supply despite no capacity increase; broad interpretation of s.3(1)

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent-State has conceded before us that the proposed alterations in the Chennur anicut do not increase the capacity of the Chennur tank. He has however very strongly contended that the proposed alterations in the Chennur anicut will increase the efficiency of the Chennur tank by making a larger supply of water available within the holding power of the tank.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e is numberdispute before us that the Chennur tank as well as the four tanks from which the appellants get a supply of water for irrigating their land

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; efficiency depends on water quantity; direct relation via supply channel

arguments.claim: Efficiency of tank depends on quantity of water available; alterations to anicut improve it

anchor.surface_text: The efficiency of a tank depends in a large measure upon the quantity of Water that is available for irrigation purpose. Without sufficient volume of water, a tank could not fulfill the purpose for which it was dug.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d that if by the proposed alterations in the Chennur anicut there is a, larger supply of water to the Chennur tank through its supply channel, then th

arguments.claim: s.3(1) measures must have direct and proximate relation to tank; cannot go far up river

anchor.surface_text: A question was mooted before us as to how far the State Government can go up the river in order to improve the Chennur tank. Perhaps, the answer to that question is that the improvement measures proposed to be taken must have a direct and proximate relation to the tank, the efficiency of which is to be increased.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, well settled and this Court has so ruled in more than one decision, that legislative proceedings cannot be referred to for the purpose of construing an Act or its provisions

anchor.surface_text: the scope of the two statutes was different one dealt with private irrigation works and the other with improvement of irrigation tanks situate in a ryotwari, zamindari, inamdari, or other area and furthermore, the proposed alterations in the Chennur anicut would not amount to improvement of any irrigation work within the scope of the 1943 Act.

anchor.surface_text: A written statement was filed by the State of Andhra Pradesh, as also by the 4th defendant, in which it was averred that the proposed alterations to the Chennur anicut would not injuriously affect the rights of the appellants and certain details were given as to the flow of water in the river at different times.

arguments.claim: s.4 bars even suits for declaration against State

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents suggested an alternative submission for our consideration. He attempted to construe s. 4 in such a way as would, in his view, bar even a suit for declaration against the State Government.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat they asked for was a declaration which they said the State Government must obey and. would be th

arguments.court_reasoning: Unwarranted reconstruction adding words not in section

holdings.text: The measures which the State Government are proposing to take in the matter of improving the Chennur anicut are measures which come within s. 3(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the view concurrently taken by the courts below is the correct view and the measures which the State Government are proposing to take in the matter of improving the Chennur anicut are measures which come within s. 3 (1) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Efficiency of tank depends on water quantity available; alterations to anicut increase supply through channel directly connected to tank; purposive interpretation of 'any other measures for increasing its capacity or efficiency'.

holdings.text: Having regard to the pleadings and the reliefs asked for, the suit was in reality a suit for restraining the State Government from exercising its powers under s. 3, though framed as a suit for mere declaration; it would be a circumvention of s. 4 to entertain it.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the courts below that having regard to the pleadings and the reliefs asked for, the suit was in reality a suit for restraining the State Government from exercising its powers under s. 3, though framed in such a manner as to give the appearance of a suit for mere declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declaration would bind State and restrain s.3 powers, equivalent to prohibited injunction; futile under s.42 Specific Relief Act.

holdings.text: The order dated February 15, 1952 (Ex. B-1) was based on Board of Revenue communication advising action under s.3(1); Government purported to act under s.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rightly pointed out that the order dated February 15, 1952, Ex. B-1 was based on the communication of the Board of Revenue dated April 8, 1950 Ex. B-10 and that communication states clearly enough that Government was advised that it could take action under s. 3 (1) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire proceeding shows intent under s.3(1); G.O. based on explicit advice.

holdings.text: Non-publication of notice under r.5 does not stand in the way of application of s.4 as action not yet taken at suit filing.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, it is unnecessary to determine at this stage whether r.5 is mandatory or merely directory, and we do not think that non-publication of the notice in the circumstances can stand in the way of the application of s. 4 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice publication pending; s.4 applies to suits restraining exercise of s.3 powers before completion.

holdings.text: Validity of s.3(1) not challenged below; new point not allowed in special leave appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As to the fourth and last point, it is sufficient to point out that the validity of s. 3 (1) was not challenged in any of the courts below and in an appeal by special leave, counsel for the appellants cannot be allowed to take a point which was not urged before.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 does not permit new points not urged in lower courts.

holdings.text: s.4 of the Act applies and bars entertainment of the suit; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we would dismiss this appeal with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; lower courts' finding on preliminary issue correct after analysis of s.3(1) scope, suit nature, government intent.

holdings.text: Legislative proceedings cannot be referred to for construing an Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, well settled and this Court has so ruled in more than one decision, that legislative proceedings cannot be referred to for the purpose of construing an Act or its provisions,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Supreme Court precedents excluding legislative history.

holdings.text: Improvement measures under s.3(1) must have direct and proximate relation to the tank.

anchor.surface_text: A question was mooted before us as to how far the State Government can go up the river in order to improve the Chennur tank. Perhaps, the answer to that question is that the improvement measures proposed to be taken must have a direct and proximate relation to the tank,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits scope to proximate measures; qualified by 'perhaps'.

holdings.text: Narasimham J.'s observations on merits unjustified as case not decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, point out that Narasimham, J., in the course of his judgment made some observations regarding the merits of the claim of the appellants which were not justified and may prejudice the appellants in subsequent proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case decided on preliminary issue only.

edges.explanation: The fact explicitly states that Chennur tank and appellants' tanks are irrigation tanks within the meaning of the Act with no dispute, directly satisfying the definition in Section 2(d).
The undisputed fact that the tanks are irrigation tanks within the Act supports the holding that the proposed measures on Chennur anicut are within s.3(1).
The fact establishing the tanks as irrigation tanks under the Act supports affirmative resolution of the issue regarding powers under s.3(1) for alterations to Chennur anicut.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the view concurrently taken by the courts below is the correct view and the measures which the State Government are proposing to take in the matter of improving the Chennur anicut are measures which come within s. 3 (1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the courts below that having regard to the pleadings and the reliefs asked for, the suit was in reality a suit for restraining the State Government from exercising its powers under s. 3, though framed in such a manner as to give the appearance of a suit for mere declaration.
For the reasons given above, we would dismiss this appeal with companyts.
